image.altText: Ken Wyatt speaking from the podium on the Yes campaign.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

title.children: Former Liberal minister says Dutton's Voice arguments are 'not factual' and 'create fear and division'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has been a vocal campaigner against the Voice. Speaking to AM's Sabra Lane in his final message to voters, he's remaining steadfast in his view that a Voice to Parliament will not improve the lives of First Nation's people. "I think there’s a lot of regret in the division that's been created, the money that's been expended and no practical outcome," he said "I think it would have been a very significant and detrimental change to our government, so I think there will be a sense of relief." When asked what he thinks the next steps should be if the No vote prevails, Mr Dutton zeroed in on money. "I think there needs to be a very close look at the money being spent in communities, I think there's a lot of angst in communities," he said. "I think the amount of money that's tipped into the top of the funnel in Canberra, the money is going somewhere and it's not going to the people in need." Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Detrimental change to our government': Opposition Leader Peter Dutton's final No push

featuredLink.title: Peter Dutton's final Referendum message - ABC listen

children.content: Federal Opposition Leader
Peter Dutton
has been a vocal campaigner against the Voice.
Speaking to AM's
Sabra Lane
in his final message to voters, he's remaining steadfast in his view that a Voice to Parliament will not improve the lives of First Nation's people.
"I think there’s a lot of regret in the division that's been created, the money that's been expended and no practical outcome," he said
"I think it would have been a very significant and detrimental change to our government, so I think there will be a sense of relief."
When asked what he thinks the next steps should be if the No vote prevails, Mr Dutton zeroed in on money.
"I think there needs to be a very close look at the money being spent in communities, I think there's a lot of angst in communities," he said.
"I think the amount of money that's tipped into the top of the funnel in Canberra, the money is going somewhere and it's not going to the people in need."
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In April of this year, former Liberal minister Ken Wyatt split with the Coalition after Opposition Leader Peter Dutton announced the party's decision to support the "No" vote. Speaking to RN's Patricia Karvelas, Mr Wyatt said he was "disappointed" with Mr Dutton's behaviour in the lead-up to the referendum. "I'm disappointed because Peter was part of the process, he had access to the information and he never had a serious discussion with me on the voice," he said. "The arguments that he's putting forward are not factual, they're contentious in order to create fear and division and they are intentional in order to sink the voice." Mr Wyatt agreed that much of the Liberal party's Voice messaging is "Trumpian". "Some of the tactics are copybook out of America. The fake news, the statements of 'You'll end up paying Aboriginal people', 'You'll lose land', 'You won't be able to do this'. That concerns me," Mr Wyatt said. Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Tactics are copybook out of America': Ken Wyatt on the Liberal Voice strategy

featuredLink.title: 'Tactics are copybook out of America': Ken Wyatt on the Liberal Voice strategy - ABC listen

children.content: Key Wyatt left the Liberal party in April 2023
(ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)
In April of this year,
former Liberal minister Ken Wyatt
split with the Coalition after
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
announced the party's decision to support the "No" vote.
Speaking to
RN's Patricia Karvelas,
Mr Wyatt said he was "disappointed" with Mr Dutton's behaviour in the lead-up to the referendum.
"I'm disappointed because Peter was part of the process, he had access to the information and he never had a serious discussion with me on the voice," he said.
"The arguments that he's putting forward are not factual, they're contentious in order to create fear and division and they are intentional in order to sink the voice."
Mr Wyatt agreed that much of the Liberal party's Voice messaging is "Trumpian".

"Some of the tactics are copybook out of America. The fake news, the statements of 'You'll end up paying Aboriginal people', 'You'll lose land', 'You won't be able to do this'. That concerns me," Mr Wyatt said.
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese continues his referendum eve tour with a speech in Adelaide Central Markets. "We have an opportunity for Australians to do better. To do better to show respect for the first Australians, but to do something for ourselves, as well, because we will feel better. We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote." The Prime Minister is hitting a lot of the same talking points this morning about how the Voice won't affect 97 per cent of Australians and a request for people to show "kindness" at the polls tomorrow. " Kindness costs nothing. Thinking of others costs nothing. This is a time where Australians have that opportunity to show the generosity of spirit that I see in the Australian character where at the worst of times we always see the best of the Australian character."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote', Albanese says

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at Adelaide Central Markets.
(ABC News: Brant Cumming)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
continues his referendum eve tour with a speech in Adelaide Central Markets.

"We have an opportunity for Australians to do better. To do better to show respect for the first Australians, but to do something for ourselves, as well, because we will feel better. We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote."

The Prime Minister is hitting a lot of the same talking points this morning about how the Voice won't affect 97 per cent of Australians and a request for people to show "kindness" at the polls tomorrow.

Kindness costs nothing. Thinking of others costs nothing. This is a time where Australians have that opportunity to show the generosity of spirit that I see in the Australian character where at the worst of times we always see the best of the Australian character."

(Reuters )
More than 423,000 people have now been forced to flee their homes in the Gaza Strip, the United Nations says.
The number of displaced Gazans rose by an additional 84,444 people as of late Thursday, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW Police are urging people to avoid heading into the CBD of Sydney on Sunday, where the Palestine Action Group plans to hold a rally in support of the residents of Gaza. Police have conceded they do not have powers to stop the rally going ahead, but any march has been banned. Acting Commissioner Dave Hudson says it's hoped legal advice will be provided by tomorrow, to support police plans to ensure public safety. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW Police considers special powers for pro-Palestinian rally

featuredLink.title: NSW Police considering using 'extraordinary' powers at planned Sydney pro-Palestinian rally

children.content: NSW Police are urging people to avoid heading into the CBD of Sydney on Sunday, where the Palestine Action Group plans to hold a rally in support of the residents of Gaza.
Police have conceded they do not have powers to stop the rally going ahead, but any march has been banned.
Acting Commissioner Dave Hudson says it's hoped legal advice will be provided by tomorrow, to support police plans to ensure public safety.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Foreign Affairs Penny Wong urges Australians in Israel to get on the repatriation flights, starting today. "I would urge anyone who wishes to leave, to not delay," she says. She also says Australia is engaging with Egypt and the US about seeking to establish humanitarian corridors out of Gaza, "but obviously the situation on the ground is extremely difficult". Ms Wong also stressed the importance of "calm leadership" and bringing Australians together, rather than creating division. "It is time for all of us to say we stand against all hatred, all prejudice. There is no place for anti-Semitism, as there is no place for discrimination and prejudice of any kind. It is a time for us to come together. "We know this is distressing for the Jewish community. We know there are many in Australia who have very strong views about the Palestinian aspirations and I would say this — one of the great tragedies, apart from the horrific nature of Hamas' actions, one of the great tragedies of what they have done is they have pushed further away the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia, Egypt and US seeking to establish humanitarian corridors, Penny Wong says

props.alt: An image of Penny Wong speaking at a press conference. Behind her is Anthony Albanese.

children.content: (ABC News)
Minister for Foreign Affairs Penny Wong urges Australians in Israel to get on the repatriation flights, starting today.
"I would urge anyone who wishes to leave, to not delay," she says.
She also says Australia is engaging with Egypt and the US about seeking to establish humanitarian corridors out of Gaza, "but obviously the situation on the ground is extremely difficult".
Ms Wong also stressed the importance of "calm leadership" and bringing Australians together, rather than creating division.

"It is time for all of us to say we stand against all hatred, all prejudice. There is no place for anti-Semitism, as there is no place for discrimination and prejudice of any kind. It is a time for us to come together.

"We know this is distressing for the Jewish community. We know there are many in Australia who have very strong views about the Palestinian aspirations and I would say this — one of the great tragedies, apart from the horrific nature of Hamas' actions, one of the great tragedies of what they have done is they have pushed further away the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people."

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". Read all about it as it happens on our live blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening. Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed. Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion dollar bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year. In May, Newcrest backed the takeover offer from Newmont. Both the companies expect the deal to close in early November. A final result will become known later on Friday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors approve the biggest corporate buyout in Australia this year

children.content: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening.
Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed.
Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion dollar bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year.
In May,
Newcrest
backed the takeover offer from Newmont.
Both the companies expect the
deal to close in early November.
A final result will become known later on Friday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow. The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same. That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes. This note from CBA this morning: Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession. Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation and Israel-Gaza war sparks global recession concerns

featuredLink.title: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

children.content: Good morning!
The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow.
The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same.
That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes.
This note from CBA this morning:

Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession.
Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
